docs.lead_paragraph: The chief tax writer in the House laid out a plan today to apportion any Federal budget surpluses equally between reducing the national debt and cutting taxes, saying he wanted to shrink the Government and keep any fiscal windfall out of the hands of those politicians who would spend it. In making his proposal, the lawmaker, Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, sought to advance a new strategy among conservatives in their campaign against the size and the influence of the Federal Government even as the new world of budget prosperity takes from them the argument that huge budget deficits demand austerity.

headline.main: A House Chief Limits Uses of Any Surplus

docs.abstract: Rep Bill Archer, head of House Ways and Means Committee, outlines plan to use any Federal budget surpluses to cut taxes and national debt, news conference; says he wants to shrink Government and keep politicians from spending any fiscal windfall; holds Congressional Budget Office forecasts suggest Congress could pay off $200 billion of debt over next 10 years and cut taxes by same amount without risking new budget deficits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Client surveys by AIDS service providers show that mandatory name-reporting deters testing -- particularly among gay and bisexual men and members of racial minority groups -- and also causes many not to retrieve their test results. In New York, numerous bills attaching criminal penalties to the conduct of those infected with H.I.V. make testing even more risky. In addition to ignoring these issues, your Jan. 13 front-page article and Jan. 15 editorial about encouraging New York doctors to report people with H.I.V. to the state Health Department failed to consider how this can be especially destructive because of widespread discrimination.

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance experts say they doubt that President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old would pay for itself, because, they say, sicker and costlier patients would be the ones most likely to sign up for the new coverage. In the last two weeks, Mr. Clinton and other Administration officials have repeatedly described the proposal as fiscally responsible and ''self-financing.'' They insist that the new beneficiaries would pay the entire cost, so that there would be no need for Federal subsidies, no risk to the Medicare trust fund and no cost to current beneficiaries.

docs.lead_paragraph: For some time, it has seemed that all the fiscal news from here was good. The state is running a big budget surplus for the third year in a row. Gov. George E. Pataki boasts that he has slowed the upward spiral of spending and that the state's emergency reserve fund is larger than ever. Yet financial experts on Wall Street, in academia and elsewhere warn that while most other states have used the healthy economy of the last seven years to get their financial affairs in order, New York remains woefully ill prepared to survive another recession like the one that struck in the early 1990's. When the next downturn hits, they predict, New York may be forced to swallow the same bitter medicine it did the last time: deep spending cuts, reneging on promised tax cuts, even tax increases.

headline.main: ALBANY IS FAULTED FOR NOT PREPARING TO MEET RECESSION

docs.lead_paragraph: Not since a wave of industrial takeovers created the great oil, steel and auto companies at the beginning of the century has corporate America been reshaped by a sweep of merger activity as broad as the one taking place today. Last year alone, a record $1 trillion in mergers took place involving American companies, a pace almost unrivaled in business history.

headline.main: WAVE OF MERGERS IS RECASTING FACE OF BUSINESS IN U.S.

docs.abstract: Corporate America is being reshaped by wave of merger activity not seen since wave of industrial takeovers created great oil, steel and auto companies at beginning of century; record $1 trillion in mergers occurred in 1997 alone, at pace almost unrivaled in business history, affecting practically every industry in America; companies are combining to create new entities on scale larger than anything before, reflecting growing belief among Government regulators, and business executives, that big business is not necessarily bad; strength of merger trend is shown by fact that total dollar value of mergers in 1997 was about 50 percent higher than those in 1996, itself a record year; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dan Couvrette's 10-year marriage dissolved in 1994, which seemed like another good reason for him to leave Wedding Bells, Canada's largest bridal magazine. Two years later, he founded another magazine, Divorce. Started in Toronto, Divorce is a relatively new addition to the market of niche magazines. It is published quarterly in four regional editions: Toronto, Chicago, New York/New Jersey and Southern California and has a combined circulation of 83,000, with 25 percent sent to subscribers and newsstands and the remainder distributed free by divorce support groups, churches, businesses, lawyers and mediators.

docs.lead_paragraph: Entering into the election year debate over Medicare, the majority leader of the Senate today said he opposed President Clinton's proposal to allow hundreds of thousands of early retirees, laid off workers and uninsured people who are nearing retirement age to buy into the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. Senator Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican, said he opposed adding more people to the Medicare program before a bipartisan commission has had time to study how to keep the Medicare program solvent when the baby boom generation retires and starts seeking benefits.
